reviewText: My husband and I basically grew up on this show; along with several other 80's T.V. series and some of them have yet to be released and doubt they will be?  Lorenzo Lamas was extremely hot in this series and still is somewhat to this day, however, we are anxiously waiting for the last two seasons to come out & where wondering if anyone out there have heard of any possible release date(s)?  We would HIGHLY RECOMMEND this series to everyone, it is a well action packed show that will keep you watching for years to come (hopefully the last two seasons will not take that long to be released)...For anyone who has never watched this before, do not start with these seasons until to watch the first one completely or you will be lost and wondering why certain things happen in a certain. We hope you will enjoy this series, as we have and still do to date:0)
summary: GREAT T.V. SHOW - HOPE SEASON'S 4 & 5 AREN'T TO FAR BEHIND:0) - ????

reviewText: I can remember watching episodes on USA Network every night and then one day, inexplicably, they were gone. RENEGADE wasn't going to win any Emmy Awards. We all know that. The appeal was in the exciting storylines and the hope that one day Reno would clear his name. Because it's a syndicated show, not a network show, we never really know if seasons 2-7 will ever get released. I hope they do because I'll purchase every single one of them. This DVD set of season one is perfect for any fan of the show. Get it now and you won't regret it!

reviewText: I choose this rating because the TV show is good. What I like about the TV show is that he was a cop, and good at his job. But he committed the ultimate sin, and testified against other cops gone bad. Cops that tried to kill him, but got the woman he loved instead. Framed for murder, now he prowls the badlands. An outlaw hunting outlaws, a bounty hunter, a "Renegade". One of the most popular syndicated shows of the 1990s, "Renegade" starred action man Lorenzo Lamas as former cop Reno Raines. As a police officer, Raines testified against the corrupt cops on the force. In retaliation, the leaders of the unscrupulous bunch came gunning for him, but killed his girlfriend instead. Framed for the murder, Raines is forced to live his life on the run from the law, moving from place to place in the American Southwest. But just because he's on the lam, doesn't mean his thirst for justice has ended. Raines continues to help those in need, all while staying one step ahead of his enemies and seeking out the evidence that will clear his name. Includes all 22 episodes from Season One. What I dislike about the TV show is that I wanted to see more of it. I would recommend this TV show to other people.

Title: N/A

reviewText: The simple format of this show was actually a help for this show as opposed to making it look cheap, as in other low-budget syndicated shows of the era.Basically a redux of the 'Lone Ranger' concept, a stranger rides into town on his steel 'horse', and with the help of his loyal Indian sidekick, helps out an individual who is getting no help from the local authorities, and rides out agian at the end, while the townsfolk all say "who was that masked man?"It was a great concept 60 years ago, and its a great concept now. These are all just simple morality plays:All black and white concepts, Good vs. Evil. No 'shades of gray' to worry about. This is what gives these episodes a timeless ,ethereal feel about them.Take the show with a grain of salt and try to ignore the obvious plot holes and discrepancies and just enjoy all the good looking actors having fun with the material. You'll dig it!

reviewText: The show first telecasted on 9/17/1992 until its last telecast on 4/4/1997 for a total of 5 seasons and 110 episodes.The cast for this show are:* Reno Raines/Vince Black ..... Lorenzo Lamas* Bobby Sixkiller ..... Branscombe Richmond* Cheyenne Phillips (1992-1996) ..... Kathleen Kinmont* Lt./Marshal Donald"Dutch"Dixon ..... Stephen J. Cannell* Sgt.Frank"Woody"Bickford ..... Ron Johnson (Occasional)* Hound Adams(1993-1996) ..... Geoffrey Blake (Occasional)* Sandy Caruthers(1996-1997) ..... Sandra FergusonIn the fall of 1994 (Season 3), Dutch Dixon caught up with Reno, who then went on trail for the murder Dixon had originally pinned on him at the start of the series (Dutch Dixon is the corrupt cop hunting Reno down. It was he who had murdered the cop Reno had been framed for killing, and he had also been responsible for the fatal shooting of Reno's fiancee.)Sleazy Hound Adams was set to testify with evidence that would have exonerated Reno and pinned the crime on Dixon, but Adams doubled-crossed our hero and Reno was convicted of murder with special circumstances. While being transferred from one prison to another Reno escaped and resumed bounty hunting for Bobby and his search for Adams or other evidence to prove his innocence.The episode list for the 2nd and 3rd season are as follows:The 2nd season (22 episodes):23  The Hound  9/18/199324  The Champ  9/20/199325  White Picket Fences  9/27/199326  Dead End and Easy Money  10/4/199327  No Good Deed...  10/11/199328  The Rabbit and the Fox  10/23/199329  Endless Summer  10/25/199330  Bonnie & Claire  11/6/199331  Wheel Man  11/8/199332  Windy City Blues  11/15/199333  Honor Bound  11/22/199334  Hard Rider  1/8/199435  Charlie  1/10/199436  South of '98  1/17/199437  Hostage  1/24/199438  Rabbit Redux  1/31/199439  The Posse  2/7/199440  Once Burned, Twice Chey  2/14/199441  Sheriff Reno  2/21/199442  Murderer's Row (1)  4/25/199443  Murderer's Row (2)  5/2/199444  Carrick O'Quinn  5/9/1994The 3rd season (22 episodes):45  Dutch On the Run (part 1 of 3) 9/12/199446  The Trial of Reno Raines (part 2 of 3) 9/19/199447  Escape (part 3 of 3)  9/26/199448  The King and I  10/3/199449  Black Wind  10/10/199450  Way Down Yonder in New Orleans  10/17/199451  Rustlers' Rodeo  10/24/199452  Muscle Beach  10/31/199453  The Late Shift  11/7/199454  Thrill Kill  11/14/199455  Teen Angel  11/21/199456  Den of Thieves  1/2/199557  Rancho Escondido  1/9/199558  Cop for a Day  1/16/199559  Stalker's Moon  1/23/199560  Repo Raines  1/30/199561  Ace in the Hole  2/6/199562  Living Legend  2/13/199563  Family Ties  2/20/199564  Broken On the Wheel of Love  4/24/199565  Split Decision  5/1/199566  Hitman  5/8/1995I hope season 4 & 5 (44 episodes)will follow shortly after and that we would not have to wait along time as we did with the first season.Thank you for reading my review and have a nice day :)
summary: One of my favorite shows, I hope season 4 & 5 will follow soon

reviewText: This is a great set - 22 episodes and you have to see the gag lines. Actually their bluppers!So many of us want to idealize a bad boy, one who is misunderstood or one who appears bad but is really good.Reno Raines [Lorenzo Lamas] portrayes this attidude and a lot of skin to make some good stories come to life.And don't forget that bike!Did you know that Cheyenne Phillips [Kathleen Kinmont] was his wife at the time of Renegade - thought there was a close connection.But I kept coming back to this show to see Bobby Sixkiller [Branscombe Richmond] as I thoroughly enjoy seeing a Native American playing one. I loved his droll sense of humor.He must have been making some good money [in the program] to have that office/home on wheels.I did like getting a looksee at the episode that had Don Swayze, and his crew, villians of course - can't remember if he got killed or not.And Stephen J. Connell [playing Butch - the corrupt police officer] I didn't make the connection with him until I watched the interviews.  Writer and actor.Not to give a plug for another movie but I am looking for Lamas's 2004 movie RAPTOR ISLAND -- is it out yet?Anyway RENEGADE is a great set for those who remember it from TV and anyone who wants to try something a little different.Definitely Recommended -
summary: MODERN DAY HORSE OPERA - AND GREAT!

reviewText: BehindFalcon Crest, "Renegade" is Lorenzo Lamas's chief claim to fame and certainly the body and soul of his action hero image. What we have here is a TV show that almost perfectly encapsulates the essence of the low-budget martial arts/action movie genre of the early-to-mid '90s, and which kept Lamas in the mainstream after his tenure in soap drama. I had eyed its DVD incarnation for a few years and recently I gave in to Mill Creek's release of the first season, and that's what this review will consist of: the content of season one and, to a lesser extent, Mill Creek's production of it. It's much better than I expected...The story: dirty cops seeking to keep their illegal dealings a secret frame detective Reno Raines (Lamas) for murder, leaving his fiancé comatose in the process and him on the run. Hooking up with Native American bounty hunter Bobby Sixkiller (Branscome Richmond,The Scorpion King) and his half-sister Cheyenne (Kathleen Kinmont, Lamas' real-life wife), he takes on an alias and the mantle of bounty hunter as well ("an outlaw hunting outlaws"), as he waits for an opportunity to prove his innocence.As the star, Lorenzo Lamas does pretty good. While the Reno Raines role isn't fantastic and definitely could have been written to make him interesting beyond Lamas' sex appeal, the part definitely has room for growth and Lorenzo covers it smoothly. A more intriguing character comes in the form of Branscombe Richmond's Bobby Sixkiller, whose ongoing habit of pointing at the clichés of his Native American identity is prone to get on your nerves once in a while but he's nevertheless entertaining and extremely confident in his acting. At times I wish he was the lead instead of Lamas, and it would've been nice if he had gotten into more solo work after the show. I'm not sure how I feel about the inclusion of Kathleen Kinmont's character: Kinmont is certainly inoffensive and plays the role better than her wife-of-the-star status would assume, but I can't help but think that the role's just there for the sake of convenience, since she rarely contributes to the story as anything more than a pair of helping hands. Still, her occasional physical exploits are fun, and - underdeveloped as it is in the first season - I like the relationship between her and Bobby.Occasionally more interesting than the main cast is the series' choice in supporting stars for individual episodes. The show helps earn its genuine action movie vibe from its choice of costars, many of them staple players from the action circuit: you've got well-known guys like Cary Tagawa (Mortal Kombat) and Jesse Ventura (Predator) making satisfying appearances, but also cameos by lifetime supporting characters like Al Leong (Die Hard) and Donald Gibb (Bloodsport). Dig it.In my book, an action movie can get by without having a particularly intelligent story, but sixteen hours of TV programming can't, so how does the first installment of "Renegade" stack up? Well, the show's a lot more episodic than I normally care for - every now and then we'll look back at Reno's fiancé or what the dirty cops are up to, but there's no true overlying arc or mission - and yet I'm pleased that the episodes are mostly microcosms of action movies by themselves, making them entertaining despite the lack of show-to-show connectivity. The majority of the episodes are variations of theYojimbotemplate, with Reno & co. riding into a town en-route to a bounty and ending up helping the townsfolk with some sort of violent trouble. The topic of xenophobia is addressed frequently, along with domestic abuse, post-war syndromes, institutionalized brainwashing, and some others. Personally, I was never really convinced that Reno could get away with rolling around the country on a motorcycle while there's a warrant out for his arrest, and it's always uncomfortable to see him nonchalantly smooching a pretty woman while knowing that his wife-to-be is comatose, but in the end it's forgivable on account of the general fun that the series provides. Despite the legitimate gravity of some of its storylines, the show never takes itself too seriously. While I'd be hard-pressed to sit down and watch episode after episode, it was fun to see one or two every other day, and this way, I leisurely finished the season in a little over a month."Renegade" is an action-oriented series and therefore can't escape scrutiny over its adrenaline content. Succinctly, I didn't have high hopes but was still somewhat disappointed. Each episode is usually limited to one or two shootouts and the same amount of hand-to-hand scuffles, and sometimes there's a car chase thrown in. At least once, the season afforded itself a helicopter sequence. While this seems fine and good on the surface, the fact is that these scenes generally feel like mandatory window dressing: very little creativity is afforded the setups or choreography, and the result is that each scene feels familiar and unimportant. I was most struck by this when it came to the martial arts content: Lamas would prove himself to be an above-average film fighter in direct-to-video fare, but even though he throws nice kicks and eventually has a couple of well-rounded fights in the last two episodes, he's mostly underutilized, even when it comes to fighting another legitimate martial artist likeMichael Jai White(he would, however, make up for this somewhat with a pretty decent bout againstMartin Kovein the 22nd episode).Mill Creek's DVD release has no special features and displays noticeable cutting of pre-commercial transitions and fade-outs, but to my knowledge, none of the actual footage has been cut or censored. The picture and audio looks and sounds fine, but close scrutiny of the video on some episodes reveals apparent need for a bit more clean-up. It's nothing to gripe over, nor should it deter you from buying the set, but tech nuts might feel uncomfortable with it.If I didn't know better, I would have looked at the first season of "Renegade" and probably enjoyed it overall but pegged the show for a short run. The fact that the show ended up running for five seasons says a lot about the mindset of the American TV audience back then, and how much I had in common with them. If the rest of the series was like this season, then I'm glad that a show this fundamentally based on macho fun had such a satisfying run. Lamas fans should not be without, and general viewers who are cool to the B-movie action vibe ought to at least investigate the show online. Thumbs up.
summary: "He was a cop, and good at his job..." A Review of Season One, Mill Creek Edition

reviewText: I got my season one set of Renegade and honestly I've been watching the dvds like a mad person!! Especially the interviews with the cast members on disc six its great and honestly reading the information that the entire series of Renegade will be coming out soon I can hardly wait to get the rest of the seasons!! I actually watched all five seasons of Renegade when it was on tv until the show got taken off air then I was completely bummed out because that was a favorite show of mine and after finding it on here then getting it I am happy to say that me being bummed out was worth the wait to own the complete seasons and watch them whenever i want to. I am going to purchase seasons 2 & 3 next then anxiously wait until 4 & 5 come out then i ll get those too just to complete the collection of mine. If anyone is a Lorenzo Lamas fan like I am of back in the days of him riding his 1982 harley davidson softail being a bounty hunter with an alias name and friends that help him when he's stuck in a major bind then this show is defintily for you!! I also had just gotten seasons 2 & 3 a week ago thanks to UPS and have been watching them all now i m anxious for them to release the final two seasons: 4 & 5 so this way my collection will be complete!! Release seasons 4 & 5 of Renegade because of the anxious fans awaiting!!
